C is forâ€¦ Cloudkicker

(Image on loan from Cloudkickerâ€™s Bandcamp)

In around 2011 I discovered a number of heavy instrumental acts who rocked my bell, among them Scale the Summit, Chimp Spanner, Sithu Aye, the mighty Plini and Cloudkicker. This last is in fact a one-man act, and that man is Ben Sharp. Like a few of the others I discovered around this time, Ben writes, produces, programs and plays everything you hear, and releases his music on the splendid Bandcamp platform, rendering him truly a one-man-band.

Cloudkickerâ€™s music is very hard to categorise, though I wouldnâ€™t be a proper music journalist if I didnâ€™t at least attempt to pigeonhole him a little, so letâ€™s call it â€œheavy ambient guitar math prog metalâ€. Then again, Iâ€™m not in fact a journalist of any kind at all, so I can call it what I want, and for now I shall just say it is very good indeed.

What it also is, is varied. I donâ€™t think Ben has any grand plan in place for his releases and just writes what he feels at the time, so his works vary a lot in tone and feel. Beacons is perhaps his best known release, and that is a structured melodic yet intricate metal album whereas Fade and Let Yourself Be Huge are far more mellow and introspective, and the Portmanteau and the bafflingly titled ]]][[[ EPs are just mental. The consistent through-line of all of his music would be ever shifting textural guitar patterns. Whether itâ€™s something angular and challenging like â€œFourteen Nightsâ€ from Portmanteau or something more thoughtful like â€œLA After Rainâ€ from Fade, Ben is a genius at creating ever-shifting fabric-like textures that change and morph subtly while seeming to stay at least recognisably the same. Itâ€™s kind of the guitar equivalent of M.C. Escherâ€™s tessellating works such as â€œDay and Nightâ€, â€œMetamorphosis IIâ€ and â€œSky and Water Iâ€.

Ben is not what I would call a shredder or even perhaps a lead guitarist in the most obvious sense, but he is a master of making interesting guitar music, much â€“ perhaps all â€“ of which you can download right now (and name your own price, mind youâ€¦ yes literallyâ€¦) from his Bandcamp site. I suggest you do. If any of this frightens you, start with Fade or Woum. If not, crack on with Beacons. Personally I would get it all â€“ I know I did.

Clive recommends:

I reckon Beacons is a good place to start kicking clouds.

Video evidence

Mr. Kicker is not seemingly a particularly fanatical self promoter, and while he continues to produce and release music on a continual slow burn, finding live footage of him playing was quite a task. I mean it took me literally almost a minute on YouTube to find you the following, but find it I did. Here then, is Ben playing live with Intronaut as his backing band, performing â€œPush it way up!â€ from Beacons. I totally did find it though. Look.
